thread.title: Sheriff investigating two fatalities - Post-Tribune

author: Amy Lavalley
title: Sheriff investigating two fatalities - Post-Tribune
text:
Deputies with the Porter County Sheriff's department have responded to two fatal car accidents on U.S. 6 in Jackson Township since Saturday.
The roadway was closed between North Calumet Avenue and County Road 400 East for seven hours early Monday for investigation, cleanup and vehicle removal after a 3:06 a.m. accident in which the driver of a pickup truck was killed in a head-on collision with a semitrailer.
The driver, a South Haven man, was partially ejected from the vehicle and pronounced dead at the scene at 4:56 a.m., according to Porter County Coroner Chuck Harris. The driver's name is being withheld pending notification of his family.
The accident occurred in front of 381 E. U.S. 6 when the driver of the pickup, a maroon 1998 Ford F150, went left of center into the path of a semitrailer that was traveling westbound, Sgt. Jamie Erow, public information officer for the sheriff's department, said.
The driver of the truck, John Jerdon, 59, of Walkerton, complained of pain to his back and neck and was transported to Porter Regional Hospital. He was not issued any citations.
Toxicology reports are pending for both drivers.
The county's crash reconstruction team was called to assist at the scene, as were the Liberty Township Fire Department, Porter EMS, the Indiana Department of Transportation, Porter County Hazmat and Joe's Towing.
Early Saturday morning, Juan Luis Lamar III, 19, of Hobart, died in a single-car accident on U.S. 6 in the Jackson Farms area of Jackson Township. The accident occurred at 12:38 a.m.
Erow said witnesses saw Lamar's car, a silver 2001 Jeep, going eastbound on U.S. 6 leave the roadway to the south, travel over a gravel access road, go back up an embankment, and go airborne across U.S. 6, landing deep in a wooded area on the north side of the road.
Agencies assisting with the crash were the Liberty Township, Westville and Washington Township fire departments, and Porter EMS.
Police do not yet know if alcohol or drugs were a contributing factor in that accident.
Amy Lavalley is a freelance reporter for the Post-Tribune.
